over here in australia i found using 50mm comms pipe had a perfect ID for a golf ball. there was about a 0.5-1mm difference. i used a 50-150mm reducer, some 150mm pipe and a cap end. used a pretty wide deodorant sprayer and had the sprayer reverse/flush mounted on the top of the 150mm pipe and put a heap of HD tape around it, put a small hole for any can to push on and spray into the pipe. then used a BBQ igniter mounted on the reducing pipe kinda where the trigger on a gun would be... worked extremely well. could shoot that thing well over a football field.

I suspect what happened with the liquid spray near the end is not condensation of water but excess (un-reacted) hairspray. You probably put too much hairspray in the ignition chamber. In addition to barrel length, the fuel to oxygen ratio can also be optimized. If you've filled it with too much hairspray that would probably push air out the bottom when you displace it with the hairspray and you'll have too high of a fuel to oxygen ratio. Then even if the combustion goes to 100% completion, you still have a large excess of un-reacted hairspray fluid because there was no more oxygen left, and that excess fluid is then ejected along with the projectile.
Maybe you could test spray excess (radius of visible spray in high speed camera) vs fuel input amount (canister nozzle time). Instead of breaking a mirror for each shot you can probably use just one and avoid aiming directly at it, or perhaps make a hole and shoot inside the hole. (or cut a mirror into pieces and arrange them to make a hole surrounded by a mirrors. Then set up a stand for the gun to line up the shot so it always goes through the hole. Alternatively but less cool, you can film the spray from the back.

Hey Destin, I was watching video and when you added the metal to the potato I am not sure the metal being hard is what made it break up the target. What got me to suspect this is how the potato, not just the metal, broke through the shell leaving a perfect cut-out.I think you touched up on it later in the video with burn-rates. Basically with just the potato, its so light it moves down the barrel faster. This not only means the fuel isn't pressurized (which reduces combustion), but also means the potato leaves the gun before all of it burns. When you added the metal the heavier bullet had more inertia, which moved much slower. This kept the volume low, and the potato slow to start allowing a full combustion.

If you wanted to test this, you could do it fairly easily. Get a board and paint it white, then add black lines every inch. Film the potato launcher shooting across is in slow motion both with and without the metal. You can then use the camera to time how long each projectile took to pass one inch. Using that velocity, and the mass of the bullet you can calculate the kinetic energy: KE = 1/2*m*v^2. Then, because energy is force times distance, and force is pressure times area you can calculate the average pressure in the tube: E=F*d --> 1/2*m*v^2 = F*d --> 1/2*m*v^2 = P*A*d --> P = (m*v^2) / (2*A*d) with m being the mass of the bullet, v being its calculated velocity, A being the area of a cross section of the barrel, and d being the length of the barrel.

Anyway, I just thought it might be interesting to see if the metal just gave a hard surface to break through the shell, or if the extra mass actually gave the bullet more energy. Who know, I could be totally wrong!

I think it would be more interesting (from an engineering point of view) to use reinforcement implants instead of a big hunk of metal to harden the potato. A few pieces of taut string as rebar might do the trick, or even flat mesh might work despite separating the potato into layers. The latest video on the channel "Practical Engineering" shows the layers approach, using t-shirts and mesh in sand to create mechanically stabilized earth. The same trick might stabilize the potato material in a way that's more educational (and probably a lot safer) than turning the potato into a regular metal bullet.
